metadata.title: Anaphylaxis - Bee Sting Reaction
learning_objectives: Recognize anaphylaxis criteria (skin + respiratory OR skin + cardiovascular)
Administer epinephrine as first-line treatment without delay
Manage combined airway compromise and circulatory shock
Understand epinephrine dosing and repeat criteria
Demonstrate appropriate positioning for shock vs respiratory distress

changelog.v3.0_enhanced: New scenario created with Blueprint Structure Enhancement v2: matching config, clinical anchors, consequence templates, ECG standardization. Deterioration timing 5/9/13 min. 20-minute duration.

dispatch_info.additional_info: Bee sting, swelling, difficulty breathing, getting worse quickly

scene_description.location: Backyard garden during family barbecue, patient sitting against fence
scene_description.safety: Scene safe, no ongoing bee threat, family members present
scene_description.access: Ground level, direct access through side gate, stretcher accessible
scene_description.bystanders: Wife very anxious, adult children present, one is a nurse

patient_profile.name: Rudolf
patient_profile.personality: Anxious and frightened, cooperative, becomes less responsive as condition worsens

initial.student_sees: You arrive to find a 67-year-old man sitting on the ground leaning against a wooden fence. His face and lips are visibly swollen - angioedema is obvious. He's speaking with a hoarse, muffled voice, and you can hear stridor when he breathes in. His arms and chest are covered with raised red welts - urticaria spreading across his skin. He's scratching at the hives while struggling to breathe. His wife is kneeling beside him: 'A bee stung him about 10 minutes ago on his hand - look how swollen it is! He's allergic but hasn't been stung in 20 years. He had an EpiPen but it expired years ago.' The patient looks at you with frightened eyes and manages to say in a hoarse voice: 'Can't... breathe right... throat tight...'
initial.appearance: Facial angioedema, lip swelling, hoarse voice with stridor, widespread urticaria, anxious, pale, diaphoretic despite warm weather
initial.clinical_note: ANAPHYLAXIS with both respiratory (stridor, airway swelling) and cardiovascular (hypotension 88/60) involvement. This is life-threatening and requires IMMEDIATE epinephrine. Stridor indicates upper airway obstruction - this can progress to complete obstruction within minutes. Hypotension indicates distributive shock. ACE inhibitor use (lisinopril) may worsen angioedema.

improving.student_sees: After your treatment, the patient's condition is improving. His voice is less hoarse, and the stridor has diminished significantly. The facial swelling is starting to reduce - you can see his features more clearly now. His breathing is easier, though still slightly labored. The urticaria remains but isn't spreading further. He says in a clearer voice: 'That shot... it's helping... I can breathe better.' His color is improving and he looks less frightened. His wife is visibly relieved.
improving.appearance: Reduced angioedema, voice clearing, stridor resolving, urticaria stable, better color, less anxious
improving.clinical_note: Positive response to epinephrine. Airway improving, blood pressure stabilizing. Continue monitoring - may need second dose. Steroids and antihistamines for ongoing management. Watch for biphasic reaction (recurrence in 1-8 hours).

deteriorating.student_sees: The patient's condition is worsening rapidly. His face is now massively swollen - eyes nearly shut, lips grotesquely enlarged. His voice has become barely audible, and the stridor is now a high-pitched wheeze with each breath. He's grabbing at his throat. His skin is becoming mottled and gray despite the urticaria. He's no longer able to speak, just making gasping sounds and pointing at his throat with terrified eyes.
deteriorating.appearance: Severe angioedema, near-complete airway obstruction, unable to speak, mottled skin, severe respiratory distress, altered consciousness
deteriorating.clinical_note: Critical deterioration - airway obstruction progressing, shock worsening. Immediate epinephrine if not given, or repeat dose needed. Prepare for surgical airway if complete obstruction occurs. This patient may die within minutes without intervention.

critical.student_sees: CRITICAL: The patient is now barely conscious and making only weak, ineffective attempts to breathe. His face is massively swollen with complete upper airway obstruction. No air movement is audible. His skin is gray-blue and mottled. He's unresponsive to voice. You cannot ventilate with BVM due to complete upper airway obstruction. This is a surgical airway emergency.
critical.appearance: Complete airway obstruction, unresponsive, cyanotic, no air movement, agonal state
critical.clinical_note: Respiratory arrest from airway obstruction plus cardiovascular collapse. Without immediate intervention (surgical airway, continued epinephrine, aggressive resuscitation), death is imminent.

airway.initial: Compromised - stridor present, hoarse voice, visible pharyngeal swelling, tongue swelling beginning
airway.improving: Improving - stridor reduced, voice clearing, swelling decreasing
airway.deteriorating: Near-complete obstruction - severe stridor, unable to speak, air hunger
airway.critical: Complete obstruction - no air movement, BVM ventilation impossible

breathing.initial: RR 28, labored, inspiratory stridor, no wheeze (this is upper airway, not bronchospasm), accessory muscle use
breathing.deteriorating: RR 36, severe stridor, minimal air movement despite maximal effort

circulation.initial: HR 118, BP 88/60 (hypotensive - shock), weak pulse, pale, diaphoretic, CRT 4 seconds, warm peripheries (distributive shock)
circulation.improving: HR 95, BP 102/68, stronger pulse, better perfusion
circulation.deteriorating: HR 135, BP 72/48, thready pulse, mottled skin
circulation.critical: HR 45 (bradycardia from hypoxia), BP unrecordable, no peripheral pulses

disability.initial: GCS 14 (E4 V4 M6 - voice impaired by swelling), anxious, oriented

exposure.initial: Bee sting site on right hand - localized swelling and redness. Widespread urticaria on arms, chest, back. No injuries.
exposure.skin_findings: Raised erythematous wheals (hives) covering approximately 40% body surface. Angioedema of face, lips, tongue.

sample_history.symptoms: Throat tightness, difficulty breathing, feeling faint, itching all over, started 10 minutes after bee sting
sample_history.allergies: BEES - known severe allergy, last reaction 20 years ago required hospital admission
sample_history.past_history: Hypertension, hyperlipidemia. Previous severe bee sting reaction 20 years ago - was in hospital 3 days
sample_history.last_intake: Lunch 2 hours ago at the barbecue
sample_history.events: Was gardening, felt bee sting on right hand. Within 5 minutes developed itching, then hives appeared, then face started swelling, then difficulty breathing. Wife called ambulance when breathing became difficult.

specific_findings.sting_site: Right hand dorsum - 2cm area of localized swelling, redness, visible puncture mark
specific_findings.angioedema: Periorbital swelling (eyes half-shut), lip swelling (upper and lower), tongue swelling (visible when mouth opens), pharyngeal swelling (visible on inspection)
specific_findings.urticaria: Raised wheals 1-3cm, erythematous with central pallor, distributed on arms, chest, back, spreading to legs
specific_findings.throat_exam: Uvula swollen, posterior pharynx edematous, voice hoarse

assessment_findings.chief_complaint_detail: Patient in hoarse voice: 'Can't... breathe right... throat tight... everything itching...' Wife: 'It's getting worse so fast! Please help him!'

interpretation.mechanism: Compensatory response to distributive shock and hypoxia

ecg_findings.teaching_point: ECG in anaphylaxis shows compensatory sinus tachycardia. ECG is NOT a priority in anaphylaxis - epinephrine is the priority. ECG may show low voltage due to poor perfusion. Rule out Kounis syndrome (allergic acute coronary syndrome) if chest pain present after epinephrine.

epinephrine.mechanism: Alpha-1: vasoconstriction (raises BP, reduces angioedema). Beta-1: positive inotrope/chronotrope. Beta-2: bronchodilation, mast cell stabilization.

dosing.route_priority: IM preferred (faster absorption than SC), IV only in cardiac arrest or refractory shock

contraindications.note: NO absolute contraindications in anaphylaxis - it is ALWAYS indicated

warnings: May need repeat doses - short duration of action
Give IM not SC for faster absorption
Lateral thigh is best site (highest blood flow)
Beta-blocker patients may have reduced response - may need higher doses or glucagon

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: That shot... it's helping... I can breathe better...
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Vasoconstriction improves BP and reduces angioedema. Bronchodilation if any bronchospasm. Mast cell stabilization reduces further histamine release. Visible reduction in swelling within 5-10 minutes.
scenario_specific_response.timing_critical: Must give within 5 minutes - delay increases mortality

delivery_options.bvm_if_needed: For assisted ventilation if airway compromised

pharmacokinetics.note: Does NOT treat acute anaphylaxis - prevents biphasic reaction

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: No immediate effect. Prevents biphasic reaction 1-8 hours later.
scenario_specific_response.timing_note: Give AFTER epinephrine - steroids are NOT first-line
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Steroids do NOT treat acute anaphylaxis. Epinephrine is the ONLY first-line treatment. Steroids prevent biphasic reaction.

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: May help with urticaria and itching. Does NOT treat airway or cardiovascular compromise.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Antihistamines are adjuncts only. They do NOT treat anaphylaxis - only epinephrine does. Never delay epinephrine to give antihistamines.

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Helps support blood pressure alongside epinephrine
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Fluids support BP but do NOT replace epinephrine. Anaphylaxis can cause significant third-spacing - may need several liters.

epinephrine.patient_says: That shot... it's helping... I can breathe better...
epinephrine.clinical_effect: Stridor reducing, angioedema improving, BP rising, color improving

second_epinephrine.clinical_effect: Further improvement if first dose inadequate

5min.description: Angioedema worsening, stridor more pronounced, patient becoming confused, skin mottling appearing

9min.description: Near-complete airway obstruction, severe shock, patient barely responsive, agonal breathing attempts

13min.description: Complete airway obstruction, cardiovascular collapse, respiratory arrest, bradycardia from hypoxia, imminent cardiac arrest

critical_harm.name: beta_blocker
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Blocks epinephrine's life-saving effects, worsens bronchospasm and hypotension

if_given.patient_response: Condition deteriorates rapidly. Beta-blocker blocks the body's compensatory mechanisms and prevents epinephrine from working.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Beta-blockers are disastrous in anaphylaxis. They block the beta effects of epinephrine, worsening hypotension and bronchospasm. If patient is ON beta-blockers, may need glucagon.

worsens.name: salbutamol_alone
worsens.why_wrong: Bronchodilator does not treat anaphylaxis - only addresses bronchospasm component, not airway swelling or shock

if_given.patient_response: No improvement - this is upper airway swelling (angioedema), not bronchospasm. Salbutamol doesn't help swelling. Blood pressure still low.

worsens.teaching_point: This is ANAPHYLAXIS not asthma. The stridor is from SWELLING not bronchospasm. Salbutamol doesn't shrink swollen tissue - epinephrine does. Never substitute bronchodilators for epinephrine in anaphylaxis.

neutral.name: antihistamine_first

if_given.patient_response: Antihistamine has minimal effect on airway or blood pressure. Critical time wasted.

neutral.teaching_point: Antihistamines do NOT treat anaphylaxis. They only help with itching/hives. EPINEPHRINE is the only first-line treatment. Never delay epinephrine to give antihistamines.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Airway obstruction progresses to arrest without epinephrine. Distributive shock leads to cardiovascular collapse. Patient dies without hospital rescue.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Epinephrine is the ONLY first-line treatment for anaphylaxis. Antihistamines and steroids are adjuncts, not replacements. Without epinephrine, this patient's airway will completely obstruct and cardiovascular collapse will occur. This is a lethal omission.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: High risk of fatal arrhythmia from IV bolus. Ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation likely.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: IV epinephrine in anaphylaxis (non-arrest) causes dangerous peak concentrations that trigger arrhythmias. IM route (0.5mg to lateral thigh) is safer, effective, and standard of care. IV epinephrine is only for cardiac arrest or as continuous infusion by specialists in ICU.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Beta-blocker blocks compensatory mechanisms and prevents epinephrine from working. Worsens hypotension and bronchospasm. Critical deterioration.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Beta-blockers are absolutely contraindicated in anaphylaxis. They block epinephrine's beta effects, worsening hypotension and preventing bronchodilation. This makes the patient refractory to epinephrine treatment.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Allergic reaction on top of existing anaphylaxis. Compounds emergency.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Always verify allergies before any medication. This patient's history was available - allergies must be checked before administering any drug.

initial.description: Presenting anaphylaxis symptoms - angioedema, stridor, urticaria, hypotension. Patient conscious and speaking (hoarse voice). Airway compromised but patent. Responsive to assessment.

early_deteriorating.description: First signs of worsening - angioedema progressing, stridor more pronounced, confusion beginning, blood pressure dropping further

deteriorating.description: Clear worsening - massive angioedema, near-complete airway obstruction, barely able to vocalize, mottled skin, altered consciousness

critical.description: Life-threatening state - complete or near-complete airway obstruction, unresponsive or minimally responsive, imminent respiratory and cardiovascular arrest

improving.description: Positive response to epinephrine - angioedema reducing, stridor resolving, voice clearing, blood pressure rising, better mental status

stable.description: Stabilized after treatment - airway patent, breathing comfortable, blood pressure adequate, conscious and appropriate

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Identifies allergen exposure + skin signs + respiratory OR cardiovascular compromise

exemplary.outcome_description: Recognized anaphylaxis immediately based on multi-system presentation
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent recognition - you identified anaphylaxis based on allergen exposure, urticaria, stridor, and hypotension. This rapid diagnosis enabled immediate appropriate treatment. Your systematic assessment caught all the key criteria.

competent.feedback_template: Good recognition of anaphylaxis. You identified the multi-system nature of the emergency and proceeded with appropriate treatment before the patient reached a critical state.

developing.outcome_description: Recognition delayed - patient deteriorated significantly before diagnosis
developing.feedback_template: Recognition of anaphylaxis was delayed. By the time you identified it, Rudolf was in {patient_state_at_action} state with massive angioedema and severe airway compromise. What clinical findings would have helped you recognize this earlier?

criteria: Misdiagnosed as isolated asthma or allergic reaction
Did not proceed with appropriate treatment
novice.outcome_description: Failed to recognize anaphylaxis or misdiagnosed condition
novice.feedback_template: Anaphylaxis was not recognized. This patient had classic presentation: allergen exposure (bee sting) + skin signs (urticaria, angioedema) + respiratory compromise (stridor) + cardiovascular compromise (hypotension 88/60). This is life-threatening and requires immediate recognition. What was your diagnostic thinking?

exemplary.outcome_description: Prevented deterioration entirely - epinephrine given while patient in initial state
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent timing - epinephrine given early while Rudolf was still in initial state. You prevented him from deteriorating into critical airway obstruction. His stridor resolved, angioedema reduced, and blood pressure stabilized. This is textbook anaphylaxis management - immediate recognition and immediate epinephrine.

competent.feedback_template: Effective treatment - epinephrine administered and Rudolf improved. Some initial worsening occurred but you intervened before he reached critical state. His airway remained manageable and he responded well to treatment.

developing.feedback_template: Epinephrine was delayed until Rudolf reached {patient_state_at_action} state. At that point, he had massive angioedema with near-complete airway obstruction - this is a surgical airway emergency in the making. While treatment eventually worked, those minutes of delay allowed preventable airway compromise that put him at high risk of death. In anaphylaxis, minutes matter. What delayed your decision to give epinephrine?

criteria: Wrong medication given instead (antihistamines, steroids, bronchodilators only)
Patient reached arrest state due to delayed treatment
novice.outcome_description: Serious harm or would die without hospital rescue
novice.feedback_template: This is addressed as a Safety Gate issue - epinephrine is the ONLY first-line treatment for anaphylaxis. Without it, this patient will die from airway obstruction and cardiovascular collapse.

exemplary.outcome_description: Oxygen applied early, supporting oxygenation before significant desaturation
exemplary.feedback_template: Good airway management - oxygen applied early while SpO2 was still manageable. This prevented further hypoxic stress while preparing for definitive treatment.

competent.feedback_template: Appropriate oxygen therapy. Patient's oxygenation was supported adequately.

developing.outcome_description: Oxygen delayed until significant hypoxia occurred
developing.feedback_template: Oxygen was delayed until Rudolf's SpO2 had dropped significantly. Early oxygen is a basic supportive measure in respiratory distress. What was your reasoning for the delay?

critical_actions_checklist.action: Reassess and consider second epinephrine dose

common_errors.teaching_point: Epinephrine must be given within 3-5 minutes of recognizing anaphylaxis
common_errors.clinical_anchor: In anaphylaxis, minutes matter. Delayed epinephrine is the number one cause of anaphylaxis deaths.

common_errors.teaching_point: Antihistamines do NOT treat anaphylaxis - only epinephrine does
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Antihistamines for hives, epinephrine for life. Know the difference.

common_errors.error: Gave salbutamol thinking it was asthma
common_errors.teaching_point: Stridor is upper airway swelling, not bronchospasm. Salbutamol doesn't treat angioedema.
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Stridor = swelling. Wheeze = bronchospasm. Different sounds, different treatments.

common_errors.error: Wrong epinephrine route (IV instead of IM)
common_errors.teaching_point: IV epinephrine in anaphylaxis causes dangerous arrhythmias. IM is the correct route.
common_errors.clinical_anchor: IM epi saves lives. IV epi in anaphylaxis causes arrhythmias.

common_errors.error: Didn't recognize need for second dose
common_errors.teaching_point: Epinephrine lasts 15-20 minutes. Repeat every 5-15 minutes if symptoms persist.
common_errors.clinical_anchor: One dose may not be enough. Reassess and repeat—epinephrine is short-acting.

common_errors.error: Focused on skin findings, missed airway/circulation
common_errors.teaching_point: Hives alone isn't anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis = allergen + skin PLUS respiratory OR cardiovascular compromise.
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Hives are dramatic but don't kill. Airway swelling and shock kill. Treat the threats to life.

consequence_templates.template: When you administered epinephrine, {patient_name} was already in {patient_state_at_action} state. His angioedema had progressed significantly from the initial presentation, and his airway was in critical jeopardy. The deterioration from initial state to {patient_state_at_action} state represents preventable airway compromise. Every minute without epinephrine allowed the angioedema to worsen, increasing the risk of complete airway obstruction. This patient was minutes away from needing a surgical airway.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Studies show anaphylaxis deaths are associated with delayed epinephrine. Airway edema and cardiovascular collapse progress rapidly without treatment. Patient state progression from initial to deteriorating/critical increases mortality risk exponentially.

consequence_templates.template: Epinephrine was NEVER given. {patient_name} had life-threatening anaphylaxis with airway compromise (stridor, angioedema) and distributive shock (BP {initial_bp}/{initial_bp_diastolic}). Without epinephrine, his airway would have completely obstructed and cardiovascular collapse would have occurred. He reached {final_patient_state} state. This represents a critical failure - there is NO substitute for epinephrine in anaphylaxis. Not antihistamines, not steroids, nothing.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Failure to give epinephrine in anaphylaxis is the leading cause of preventable anaphylaxis deaths. No other medication treats the underlying pathophysiology (mast cell degranulation, vasodilation, increased vascular permeability).

consequence_templates.template: When you applied oxygen, {patient_name}'s SpO2 had already dropped to {spo2_at_action}% from the initial {initial_spo2}%. This decline represents preventable hypoxic stress. In a patient with compromised airway from angioedema, maintaining oxygenation is critical to prevent secondary brain injury.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Hypoxia compounds the emergency. Early oxygen is a basic supportive measure in respiratory distress.

critical_decision_points.description: Distinguishing anaphylaxis from isolated respiratory conditions
optimal_sequence: Note stridor (upper airway) vs wheeze (lower airway)
Identify hypotension as sign of distributive shock

scoring.optimal: Immediately recognized anaphylaxis based on allergen exposure + urticaria + stridor + hypotension. Understood this is multi-system allergic emergency, not isolated respiratory problem.
scoring.acceptable: Recognized severe allergic reaction requiring epinephrine, even if didn't articulate all diagnostic criteria.
scoring.suboptimal: Confused anaphylaxis with asthma, considered bronchodilators before epinephrine.
scoring.dangerous: Treated as asthma with salbutamol, missed anaphylaxis diagnosis, didn't give epinephrine.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Allergen + hives + stridor + shock = anaphylaxis, not asthma. The treatment is epinephrine, not bronchodilators.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Anaphylaxis criteria: allergen exposure PLUS skin involvement (urticaria/angioedema) PLUS either respiratory compromise (stridor, wheeze) OR cardiovascular compromise (hypotension). This patient had all components. Stridor indicates UPPER airway swelling - bronchodilators don't treat swelling.

critical_decision_points.description: Giving epinephrine as absolute first-line treatment

scoring.optimal: Epinephrine given as FIRST medication within 3 minutes. Other treatments (O2, fluids, steroids, antihistamines) given AFTER epinephrine.
scoring.acceptable: Epinephrine given within 5 minutes, even if oxygen given first.
scoring.suboptimal: Epinephrine delayed while giving antihistamines or steroids first.
scoring.dangerous: Epinephrine not given, or given very late (>10 min) after other medications.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: In anaphylaxis, epinephrine is THE treatment. Everything else is adjunct. There is no substitute.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Treatment priority in anaphylaxis: (1) Epinephrine IM 0.5mg - immediately. (2) Oxygen. (3) IV access and fluids. (4) Steroids and antihistamines (adjuncts only). Antihistamines treat itch, not anaphylaxis. Steroids prevent biphasic reaction, not acute anaphylaxis. ONLY epinephrine treats the core pathophysiology.

critical_decision_points.evaluate_if: First epinephrine given and symptoms persist

scoring.optimal: Reassessed at 5 minutes, recognized incomplete response, gave second dose appropriately.
scoring.acceptable: Recognized need for second dose by 10-15 minutes.
scoring.suboptimal: Did not consider second dose despite persistent symptoms.
scoring.dangerous: Never reassessed, assumed one dose was sufficient despite ongoing deterioration.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Epinephrine wears off in 15-20 minutes. Reassess and repeat—one dose may not be enough.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Epinephrine duration is short (15-20 minutes). Guidelines recommend repeating every 5-15 minutes if symptoms persist. Many patients require 2+ doses. Failure to give second dose is a common error in anaphylaxis management.

key_concepts: Anaphylaxis = allergen + skin PLUS respiratory OR cardiovascular compromise
Epinephrine is THE treatment - no substitute, no delay
Stridor = upper airway swelling (needs epinephrine), Wheeze = bronchospasm (needs bronchodilator)
Antihistamines and steroids are ADJUNCTS only - they do NOT treat anaphylaxis
May need repeat epinephrine doses - reassess frequently
clinical_pearls: IM epinephrine into lateral thigh - fastest absorption
Hypotension in anaphylaxis = distributive shock from vasodilation
ACE inhibitors (like patient's lisinopril) worsen angioedema
Biphasic reactions occur in up to 20% - that's why we give steroids
Beta-blocker patients may be refractory to epinephrine - consider glucagon
